pretext: "です" means "is," but unlike "だ," it can be used with "か" and such. "です" is also more formal. If you want to study it, you can do that once you can speak it (and it will be easier, too).

Note (you'll figure things out even if you don't read this): In terms of level of formality, you usually use words like "です" when the person you are talking to is unknown to you, when writing a formal letter, etc. You don't generally use it with your friends. "Could you use slang in this situation" is a good test. Also, only the last verb in a sentence needs to be the formal version to make the whole sentence formal ("です" is a verb meaning "to be").
